title: Porsche boss to take wheel at VW
text:
Volkswagen to name Porsche boss Matthias Meuller as new CEO September 25, 2015 5:35am Image Germany: Volkswagen CEO Winterkorn apologises for emissions scandal 2:33 
Chairman of the Board of Directors of Volkswagen AG Martin Winterkorn apologised for Volkswagen emissions scandal in a two and a half minute statement, in Wolfsburg on Tuesday. Winterkorn insisted he was "endlessly sorry" for the ongoing scandal around Volkswagen that has now widened to include some 11 million cars and promised that manipulations at Volkswagen will "never happen again." Winterkorn stated in his video message that company is "ruthlessly" investigating the issue and that everything will be solved "as fast, thoroughly and transparently as possible." He also said that "swift and comprehensive clarification now has the utmost priority.""We are guilty before our customers, workers and the whole society," said Winterkorn in his apology. But he asked all the customers and workers for their trust, explaining that Volkswagen will work "intensively" on the necessary technical solutions will do "everything possible" to prevent problems to customers and workers. At the end of the speech, Winterkorn gave his word that the company "will proceed with the utmost openness and transparency." The emissions scandal involving around 11 million vehicles erupted after U.S. car emission tests. Volkswagen has reportedly set aside $7.27 billion (?6.53 billion) to cover potential costs although some experts are estimating that the whole incident could cost the car giant a total of around $18 billion (?16 billion). Picture: AFP/Daniel Roland AFP and Network Writers News Corp Australia Network Share Email a friend 
THE head of German luxury sports carmaker Porsche, Matthias Mueller, has been picked to succeed Martin Winterkorn as the chief executive of scandal-battered auto giant Volkswagen. 
In an article to be published on Friday, the business daily Handelsblatt claims 62-year-old Mueller will take the driving seat vacated by Winterkorn on Wednesday. 
Winterkorn resigned as a consequence of the global pollution cheating scandal that has rocked the car sector over the past week. 
Senior members of the company’s supervisory board had agreed on the choice of Mueller, the report said, quoting two sources close to the board. Leaders ... Volkswagen AG CEO and Porsche Automobil Holding SE CEO Martin Winterkorn (front) and Porsche AG CEO Matthias Mueller at the annual general meeting of Porsche Automobil Holding SE in Stuttgart on June 25, 2012. Picture: AFP/Thomas Kienzle Source: AFP 
The full 20-member board would meet on Friday morning to approve the appointment, which would then be made public in the early afternoon, it added. 
Born in Chemnitz in former East Germany, Mueller originally trained as a tool maker and then graduated in information technology. 
Appointed CEO at VW’s sports car maker Porsche in 2010, the white-haired and blue-eyed Mueller enjoys the backing of the group’s family shareholders. 
He had been tipped to replace Winterkorn during the latter’s bitter feud with his one-time mentor and former supervisory board chief Ferdinand Piech earlier this year. Stepped down ... Martin Winterkorn resigned as CEO of German carmaker Volkswagen over a pollution cheating scandal that has sparked a US criminal investigation and worldwide legal action. Picture: AFP/Johannes Eisele Source: AFP 
Germany’s powerful car industry has been reeling over the revelations that Volkswagen fitted up to 11 million of its diesel cars with devices capable of fooling emissions tests.
